Name: Mrs. John Peacock
Address: N.E.O.H.A.M.
Birthplace: ONTARIO

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
   - What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? Aug. 1912
   - Where did you set up housekeeping? Spyer Rd. (Mrs. S. Mowbray)
   - Where had you been living before that? Herbert, Ont.
   - For how many people did you prepare meals? 18
   - How far was it to your nearest store? 65 miles
   - How often could a visit be made to the store? Spring & fall
   - What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? cheese, flour, syrup, sugar, tea, raisins, prunes, oatmeal, soap, cornmeal, molasses, salt

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
   - What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Robinhood
   - In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs., 60 lbs., more each at once
   - What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour?
   - How much did you use Graham flour? None
   - Whole wheat flour? None
   - Was flour milled locally? Yes, how far away? 17½ miles, what year? around 1912
   - What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
   - What other grain products did you use?
     - Cornmeal? Yes
     - Whole wheat? No
     - Farina? Yes
     - Other?
   - Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes, first year
   - How did you grind it? By hand in small coffee grinder

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Summer:
- breakfast - fried potatoes, eggs, porridge, bread & butter, milk & sugar
- dinner - meat, potatoes, gravy, vegetable
- rice pudding, milk
- supper - potatoes, eggs, bread, butter, fruit

1914:
Me -
Pa -
Five boys - 19, 17, 7, 5, 3.
Three girls - 14, 12, 10.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in western Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Just the family.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

The winter of 1913-14 we used wheat both ground (in our coffee mill) as porridge & boiled whole. Had no milk & only chokecherry jam for fruit. Pretty slim fare.

I'm the "hungry 30's" while we didn't starve we certainly did not have adequate food for good health.
Much of the food came to the merchant. It did not go back to the merchant. It did not go back to the merchant.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest war years. You can remember. Give the war and list the numbers of the really war years. Give the approximate date, e.g., winter or summer.

Summer breakfast - fried potatoes, milk, jam, family breakfast dinner - meat, potatoes, gravy, vegetables

1914. Mrs. Pa - 19, 17, 7, 5, 3

These girls - 14, 12, 10
